Posts.Content: MelanieLHG wrote: Hi, I am 35 and had had micro invasive DCIS two years ago (for the second time).  I was counted as high risk due to my family history so had a bilateral mastecomy and rads.  I recently went to my GP to get my marina coil replaced but my GP said she would not do it because of the hormones in the device and has referred me to a gynecologist (waiting to see her).  However I had my six month post cancer check up at the hospital today so I asked if my cancer had been hormone receptive (thinking this would clear up the contreception dilemma), it turns out that for DCIS they do not test for this.  That seems a bit crazy to me, wouldnt it bee a good idea that they know so that I could be given drugs to lower my hormones if that was the case.  It also now makes contrecption decisions difficult.  I like the marina coil as it stops my periods (which were pretty heavy before) and I get much fewer spots (as I used to get a lot).  I feel better with the marina coil, yet because I do not know if I am hormone receptive I do not know if it is safe to use and what the risks are if I did. Is it normal to not be tested for hormone receptive when having DCIS?  Will they still have the samples they took and can they now be tested? What have peoples consultants/oncologists advised you about the marina coil? Any comments would be appreciated.  I thought all this cancer stuff was out of the way so feeling a bit :( that I now have this dilemma. M x Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Contraception dilemma MelanieLHG MelissaDallas
